WARNING: The flow will be marked as WARNING.
The next tasks will be execute.
The error tasks will be execute.
FAILED: The flow will be marked as FAILED.
No other task will be execute.
The error tasks will be execute.
SUCCESS: The flow will restart as this task was success.
All the blocked tasks will be execute.
The flow will be on SUCCESS if all the tasks are also SUCCESS.
RUNNING: The flow will restart and will execute all next tasks.
All the blocked tasks will be execute.

Here is the list of concerned flows:

step1.title: Welcome to Kestra's flow editor!
step1.content: Did you know that Kestra uses YAML, a simple and easy-to-read declarative language? This means that you can easily define your flows by writing out the steps in plain text. Don't worry if you still need to become familiar with YAML; we'll guide you through it step by step.

step2.title: This is the Kestra Editor
step2.content: The Kestra editor is where you will write the YAML that describes your flow. Comments start with #. Tasks type and attributes can be searched thanks to the autocomplete feature with CTRL or âŒ˜ + SPACE.

step3.title: Let's start with your first flow
step3.content: The first step to define a flow is to give it an ID, a namespace, and, optionally, a description.

step4.title: Define inputs
step4.content: The next step is to define the inputs of your flow. This is done by giving each input a name and a type.

step5.title: Add tasks
step5.content: Then, you can add tasks to your flow. A task is a step in your flow that will execute a specific action. For example, you can use a task to execute a SQL query or to send an email.

step6.title: Logs some information
step6.content: First, let's start by adding a task that will log some information. This task will be executed when the flow is triggered and log The flow starts.

step7.title: Download a file
step7.content: Sometimes, you want to download a file from a remote server. This can be done by using the Download task. This task will download the file into Kestra's internal storage.

step8.title: Use Python to do analytics
step8.content: Maybe this file contains some interesting data? Let's use Python and Pandas to do some analytics on it! This task uses the output of the previous task via the outputs.downloadData.uri variable and defines an output named sumOfConsumption thanks to the Kestra Python library.

step9.title: Save your flow
step9.content: You're all set! Now, you can save your flow by clicking on the Save button.

step10.title: Now execute your flow!
step10.content: You can execute your flow by clicking on the New execution button.

step11.title: Enter inputs
step11.content: Finally, if your flow has inputs, you will be asked to enter them before executing the flow. We have already fill the input for you with a default value.

onboarding-flow.onboardComment1: Flow declaration with a mandatory unique identifier, a namespace, and an optional description.
onboarding-flow.onboardComment2: Flow identifier are unique inside a namespace.
onboarding-flow.inputs: Flow inputs: each input has a name, a type, and an optional default value.
onboarding-flow.inputsDetails1: We define one input of name 'csvUrl' with as default value the URL of the test data file.
onboarding-flow.inputsDetails2: This test data is from the France Open Data portal and contains french electricity consumptions in CSV.
onboarding-flow.tasks1: List of tasks that will be executed one after the other.
onboarding-flow.tasks2: Each task must have an identifier unique for the flow and a type.
onboarding-flow.tasks3: Depending on the type of the task, you may have to pass additional attributes.
onboarding-flow.taskLog1: This is one of the simplest task: it echos a message in the log, like the 'echo' command.
onboarding-flow.taskLog2: The message is passed thanks to the 'format' attribute.
onboarding-flow.taskDL: This task will download the CSV, it will be sent to Kestra's internal storage and available from the task output.
onboarding-flow.taskDLUri1: Here we use a variable from an input: {'{{'} and {'}}'} are separator of a Pebble expression in which we can access variables.
onboarding-flow.taskDLUri2: All inputs are available from the 'inputs' variable using there name.
onboarding-flow.taskPython: This task will analyse the CSV data using a Python script with the Pandas library.
onboarding-flow.taskPythonCSV1: Here we define a file named 'data.csv' that will be available in the Python task working directory.
onboarding-flow.taskPythonCSV2: This file is fetched from the internal storage by using the 'uri' output of the 'downloadData' task.
onboarding-flow.taskPythonMain1: 'main.py' is the Python script that will be executed.
onboarding-flow.taskPythonMain2: It uses Pandas to read the CSV file, compute the sum of the 'conso' column,
onboarding-flow.taskPythonMain3: and set it as task output thanks to the Kestra Python library.
onboarding-flow.taskPythonRequirements: As the script require the Pandas library, we must list it in the requirements.
